The **ICC World Twenty20** (also referred to as the **World T20** , and
colloquially as the **T20 World Cup**) is the international championship of
[Twenty20 cricket](/wiki/Twenty20_cricket "Twenty20 cricket"). Organised by
[cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket")'s governing body, the [International
Cricket Council](/wiki/International_Cricket_Council "International Cricket
Council") (ICC), the tournament currently consists of 16 teams, comprising all
ten [ICC full
members](/wiki/List_of_International_Cricket_Council_members#Full_Members
"List of International Cricket Council members") and six other associate or
affiliate members chosen through the [World Twenty20
Qualifier](/wiki/ICC_World_Twenty20_Qualifier "ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier").
All matches played are accorded [Twenty20
International](/wiki/Twenty20_International "Twenty20 International") status.

The event has generally been held every two years. However, the next edition
of the tournament is scheduled to take place [in 2020 in
Australia](/wiki/2020_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2020 ICC World Twenty20"), four
years after the conclusion of the [2016 edition](/wiki/2016_ICC_World_Twenty20
"2016 ICC World Twenty20"). In May 2016, the ICC put forward the idea of
having a tournament in 2018, with South Africa being the possible host.[3] But
at the conclusion of the [2017 ICC Champions
Trophy](/wiki/2017_ICC_Champions_Trophy "2017 ICC Champions Trophy"), the ICC
announced that the next edition of the World T20 would take place in 2020 in
Australia, as originally scheduled.[4]

Six tournaments have so far been played, and only the West Indies, who
currently hold the title, has won the tournament on multiple occasions. The
inaugural event, the [2007 World Twenty20](/wiki/2007_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2007
ICC World Twenty20"), was staged in South Africa, and won by
[India](/wiki/India_national_cricket_team "India national cricket team"), who
defeated [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_national_cricket_team "Pakistan national
cricket team") in the final at the [Wanderers Stadium](/wiki/Wanderers_Stadium
"Wanderers Stadium") in [Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg"). The
[2009 tournament](/wiki/2009_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2009 ICC World Twenty20")
took place in England, and was won by the previous runner-up, Pakistan, who
defeated [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka_national_cricket_team "Sri Lanka national
cricket team") in the final at [Lord's](/wiki/Lord%27s "Lord's"). The [third
tournament](/wiki/2010_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2010 ICC World Twenty20") was held
in 2010, hosted by the countries making up the [West Indies cricket
team](/wiki/West_Indies_cricket_team "West Indies cricket team").
[England](/wiki/England_national_cricket_team "England national cricket team")
defeated [Australia](/wiki/Australia_national_cricket_team "Australia national
cricket team") in the final in [Barbados](/wiki/Barbados "Barbados"), which
was played at [Kensington Oval](/wiki/Kensington_Oval "Kensington Oval"). The
fourth tournament, the [2012 World Twenty20](/wiki/2012_ICC_World_Twenty20
"2012 ICC World Twenty20"), was held in Asia for the first time, with all
matches played in [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka"). The West Indies
won the tournament by defeating Sri Lanka in the final, winning its first
international tournament since the [2004 Champions
Trophy](/wiki/2004_ICC_Champions_Trophy "2004 ICC Champions Trophy").[5] The
fifth tournament, the [2014 ICC World Twenty20](/wiki/2014_ICC_World_Twenty20
"2014 ICC World Twenty20"), was hosted by [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh
"Bangladesh"), and was won by Sri Lanka, who became the first team to play in
three finals. West Indies are the current World T20I holders, beating
[England](/wiki/England_national_cricket_team "England national cricket team")
in the 2016 final, winning their second title.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Main article: [History of the ICC World
Twenty20](/wiki/History_of_the_ICC_World_Twenty20 "History of the ICC World
Twenty20")

###
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Background")]

When the [Benson & Hedges Cup](/wiki/Benson_%26_Hedges_Cup "Benson & Hedges
Cup") ended in 2002, the [ECB](/wiki/England_and_Wales_Cricket_Board "England
and Wales Cricket Board") needed another one day competition to fill its
place. Cricketing authorities were looking to boost the game's popularity with
the younger generation in response to dwindling crowds and reduced
sponsorship. It was intended to deliver fast-paced, exciting cricket
accessible to thousands of fans who were put off by the longer versions of the
game. Stuart Robertson, the marketing manager of the ECB, proposed a 20 over
per innings game to county chairmen in 2001 and they voted 11–7 in favour of
adopting the new format.[6]

Regional tournaments

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/2007t20.jpg/280px-2007t20.jpg)](/wiki/File:2007t20.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2007t20.jpg "Enlarge")

Bangladesh V South Africa at the 2007 tournament

The first official Twenty20 matches were played on 13 June 2003 between the
English counties in the [Twenty20 Cup](/wiki/Twenty20_Cup "Twenty20 Cup").[7]
The first season of Twenty20 in England was a relative success, with the
[Surrey Lions](/wiki/Surrey_County_Cricket_Club "Surrey County Cricket Club")
defeating the [Warwickshire Bears](/wiki/Warwickshire_County_Cricket_Club
"Warwickshire County Cricket Club") by 9 wickets in the final to claim the
title.[8] The first Twenty20 match held at [Lord's](/wiki/Lord%27s "Lord's"),
on 15 July 2004 between [Middlesex](/wiki/Middlesex_County_Cricket_Club
"Middlesex County Cricket Club") and [Surrey](/wiki/Surrey_County_Cricket_Club
"Surrey County Cricket Club"), attracted a crowd of 27,509, the largest
attendance for any [county cricket](/wiki/County_cricket "County cricket")
game at the ground other than a one-day final since 1953.[9]

Soon after with the adoption of Twenty20 matches by other cricket boards, the
popularity of the format grew with unexpected crowd attendance, new regional
tournaments such as Pakistan's [Faysal Bank T20 Cup](/wiki/Faysal_Bank_T20_Cup
"Faysal Bank T20 Cup") and [Stanford 20/20](/wiki/Stanford_20/20 "Stanford
20/20") tournament and the financial incentive in the format.

The West Indies regional teams competed in what was named the [Stanford
20/20](/wiki/Stanford_20/20 "Stanford 20/20") tournament. The event was
financially backed by convicted fraudster [Allen
Stanford](/wiki/Allen_Stanford "Allen Stanford"), who gave at least
US$28,000,000 funding money, the fruit of his massive Ponzi scheme. It was
intended that the tournament would be an annual event.
[Guyana](/wiki/Guyanese_cricket_team "Guyanese cricket team") won the
inaugural event, defeating [Trinidad and
Tobago](/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago_cricket_team "Trinidad and Tobago cricket
team") by 5 wickets, securing US$1,000,000 in prize money.[10][11] A spin-off
tournament, the [Stanford Super Series](/wiki/Stanford_Super_Series "Stanford
Super Series"), was held in October 2008 between
[Middlesex](/wiki/Middlesex_County_Cricket_Club "Middlesex County Cricket
Club") and [Trinidad and
Tobago](/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago_national_cricket_team "Trinidad and Tobago
national cricket team"), the respective winners of the English and Caribbean
Twenty20 competitions, and a [Stanford Superstars](/wiki/Stanford_Superstars
"Stanford Superstars") team formed from West Indies domestic players; Trinidad
and Tobago won the competition, securing US$280,000 prize money.[12][13] On 1
November, the Stanford Superstars played England in what was expected to be
the first of five fixtures in as many years with the winner claiming a
US$20,000,000 in each match.[14][15]

Twenty20 Internationals

Main article: [Twenty20 International](/wiki/Twenty20_International "Twenty20
International")

On 17 February 2005 [Australia](/wiki/Australian_cricket_team "Australian
cricket team") defeated [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand_cricket_team "New
Zealand cricket team") in the first men's full international Twenty20 match,
played at [Eden Park](/wiki/Eden_Park "Eden Park") in
[Auckland](/wiki/Auckland "Auckland"). The game was played in a light-hearted
manner – both sides turned out in kit similar to that worn in the 1980s, the
New Zealand team's a direct copy of that worn by the [Beige
Brigade](/wiki/Beige_Brigade "Beige Brigade"). Some of the players also
sported moustaches/beards and hair styles popular in the 1980s taking part in
a competition amongst themselves for _best retro look_ , at the request of the
Beige Brigade. Australia won the game comprehensively, and as the result
became obvious towards the end of the NZ innings, the players and umpires took
things less seriously – [Glenn McGrath](/wiki/Glenn_McGrath "Glenn McGrath")
jokingly replayed the [Trevor Chappell](/wiki/Trevor_Chappell "Trevor
Chappell") [underarm incident](/wiki/1981_underarm_bowling_incident "1981
underarm bowling incident") from a 1981 ODI between the two sides, and [Billy
Bowden](/wiki/Billy_Bowden "Billy Bowden") showed him a mock [red
card](/wiki/Red_card_\(sports\) "Red card \(sports\)") (red cards are not
normally used in cricket) in response.

### Inaugural
tournaments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Inaugural tournaments")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/T20_final_2009.jpg/220px-T20_final_2009.jpg)](/wiki/File:T20_final_2009.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:T20_final_2009.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lasith Malinga](/wiki/Lasith_Malinga "Lasith Malinga") bowling to Shahid
Afridi in the [2009](/wiki/2009_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2009 ICC World Twenty20")
Final at [Lord's](/wiki/Lord%27s "Lord's").

It was first decided that every two years an ICC World Twenty20 tournament is
to take place, except in the event of an [Cricket World
Cup](/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup "Cricket World Cup") being scheduled in the same
year, in which case it will be held the year before. The first tournament was
in [2007 in South Africa](/wiki/2007_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2007 ICC World
Twenty20") where [India](/wiki/India_cricket_team "India cricket team")
defeated [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_cricket_team "Pakistan cricket team") in
the final. Two Associate teams had played in the first tournament, selected
through the [2007 ICC World Cricket League Division
One](/wiki/2007_ICC_World_Cricket_League_Division_One "2007 ICC World Cricket
League Division One"), a 50-over competition. In December 2007 it was decided
to hold a qualifying tournament with a 20-over format to better prepare the
teams. With six participants, two would qualify for the [2009 World
Twenty20](/wiki/2009_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2009 ICC World Twenty20") and would
each receive $250,000 in prize money.[16] The [second
tournament](/wiki/2009_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2009 ICC World Twenty20") was won
by [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_cricket_team "Pakistan cricket team") who beat
[Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka_cricket_team "Sri Lanka cricket team") by 8
wickets in England on 21 June 2009. The [2010 ICC World
Twenty20](/wiki/2010_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2010 ICC World Twenty20") tournament
was held in West Indies in May 2010, where
[England](/wiki/England_cricket_team "England cricket team") defeated
[Australia](/wiki/Australia_cricket_team "Australia cricket team") by 7
wickets. The [2012 ICC World Twenty20](/wiki/2012_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2012 ICC
World Twenty20") was won by the West-Indies, by defeating Sri Lanka at the
finals. For the first time, a host nation competed in the final of the ICC
World Twenty20. There were 12 participants for the title including
[Ireland](/wiki/Ireland_cricket_team "Ireland cricket team") and
[Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan_national_cricket_team "Afghanistan national
cricket team") as [2012 ICC World Twenty20
Qualifier](/wiki/2012_ICC_World_Twenty20_Qualifier "2012 ICC World Twenty20
Qualifier"). It was the first time the T20 World Cup tournament took place in
an Asian country.

### Expansion to 16
teams[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Expansion to 16 teams")]

The [2012](/wiki/2012_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2012 ICC World Twenty20") edition
was to be expanded into a 16 team format however this was reverted to 12.[17]
The [2014](/wiki/2014_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2014 ICC World Twenty20")
tournament, held in [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") was the first
to feature 16 teams including all ten [full
members](/wiki/List_of_International_Cricket_Council_members#Full_Members
"List of International Cricket Council members") and six [associate
members](/wiki/List_of_International_Cricket_Council_members#Associate_Members
"List of International Cricket Council members") who qualified through the
[2013 ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier](/wiki/2013_ICC_World_Twenty20_Qualifier
"2013 ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier"). However the top eight full member teams
in the [ICC T20I Championship](/wiki/ICC_T20I_Championship "ICC T20I
Championship") rankings on 8 October 2012 were given a place in the Super 10
stage. The remaining eight teams competed in the group stage, from which two
teams advance to the Super 10 stage.[18][19] Three new teams (Nepal, Hong Kong
and UAE) made their debut in this tournament.

## Format[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Format")]

###
Qualification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Qualification")]

See also: [ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier](/wiki/ICC_World_Twenty20_Qualifier
"ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier")

All ICC full members qualify automatically for the tournament, with the
remaining places filled by other ICC members through a qualification
tournament, known as the [World Twenty20
Qualifier](/wiki/ICC_World_Twenty20_Qualifier "ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier").
Qualification for the inaugural [2007 World
Twenty20](/wiki/2007_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2007 ICC World Twenty20") came from
the results of the first cycle of the [World Cricket
League](/wiki/World_Cricket_League "World Cricket League"), a 50-over league
for ICC associate and affiliate members. The two finalists of the [2007 WCL
Division One](/wiki/2007_ICC_World_Cricket_League_Division_One "2007 ICC World
Cricket League Division One") tournament,
[Kenya](/wiki/Kenya_national_cricket_team "Kenya national cricket team") and
[Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_cricket_team "Scotland national cricket
team"), qualified for the World Twenty20 later in the year. A separate
qualification tournament was implemented for the [2009 World
Twenty20](/wiki/2009_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2009 ICC World Twenty20"), and has
been retained since then. The number of teams qualifying through the World
Twenty20 Qualifier has varied, however, ranging from two (in
[2010](/wiki/2010_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2010 ICC World Twenty20") and
[2012](/wiki/2012_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2012 ICC World Twenty20")) to six (in
[2014](/wiki/2014_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2014 ICC World Twenty20") and
[2016](/wiki/2016_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2016 ICC World Twenty20")).

### Final
tournament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Final tournament")]

In each group stage (both the preliminary round and the Super 10 round), teams
are ranked against each other based on the following criteria:[20]

  1. Higher number of points
  2. If equal, higher number of wins
  3. If still equal, higher [net run rate](/wiki/Net_run_rate "Net run rate")
  4. If still equal, lower [bowling strike rate](/wiki/Strike_rate#Bowling_strike_rate "Strike rate")
  5. If still equal, result of head to head meeting.

In case of a [tie](/wiki/Tie_\(draw\) "Tie \(draw\)") (that is, both teams
scoring the same number of runs at the end of their respective innings), a
[Super Over](/wiki/Super_Over "Super Over") would decide the winner. In the
case of a tie occurring again in the Super Over, the match is won by the team
that has scored the most [sixes](/wiki/Boundaries_\(cricket\) "Boundaries
\(cricket\)") in their innings. This is applicable in all stages of the
tournament, having been implemented during the 2009 tournament. During the
2007 tournament, a [bowl-out](/wiki/Bowl-out "Bowl-out") was used to decide
the loser of tied matches.[21]

## Hosts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Hosts")]

The International Cricket Council's executive committee votes for the hosts of
the tournament after examining bids from the nations which have expressed an
interest in holding the event. After South Africa in 2007, England, [West
Indies](/wiki/West_Indies "West Indies") and [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri
Lanka") hosted the tournament in 2009, 2010 and 2012 respectively.
[Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") hosted the tournament in 2014.[22]
[India](/wiki/India "India") hosted the last edition of the tournament in
2016.[23]

In December 2015, Tim Anderson, the ICC's head of global development,
suggested that a future tournament be hosted by the United States. He believed
that hosting the event could help spur growth of the game in the country,
where it is relatively obscure and faces competition by other sports such as
[baseball](/wiki/Baseball "Baseball").[24]

## Team results by
tournament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ICC_World_Twenty20&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Team results by tournament")]

The ICC does not adjudicate rankings but only rounds a team achieves e.g.
Semis, round one etc. The table below provides an overview of the performances
of teams in the ICC World Twenty20.

Legend

  * C — Champions
  * RU — Runners-up
  * SF — Semi-finalist
  * R2 — Round 2 (Super 8s, Super 10s)
  * R1 — Round 1 (Group stage)
  * ••  — Qualified but withdrew
  * •  — Did not qualify
  * ×  — Did not enter / Withdrew

The team ranking in each tournament is according to ICC. For each tournament,
the number of teams in each finals tournament (in brackets) are shown.
